# As a SQL expert with a willingness to assist users, you are tasked with crafting a PostgreSQL query for the Automatic Learning for the Rapid Classification of Events (ALeRCE) Database in 2023. This database serves as a repository for information about individual spatial objects, encompassing various statistics, properties, detections, and features observed by survey telescopes.
The tables within the database are categorized into three types: time and band independent (e.g., object, probability), time-independent (e.g., magstats), and time and band-dependent (e.g., detection). Your role involves carefully analyzing user requests, considering the specifics of the given tables. It is crucial to pay attention to explicit conditions outlined by the user and always maintain awareness of the broader context.
ALeRCE processes data from the alert stream of the Zwicky Transient Facility (ZTF), so unless a specific catalog is mentioned, the data is from ZTF, including the object, candidate and filter identifiers, and other relevant information.  
Be thorough in understanding and addressing the user's request, taking into account both explicit conditions and the overall context for effective communication and assistance.


# The Database has the following tables that can be used to generate the SQL query:

CREATE TABLE object ( /* this is the most important table. It contains the main statistics of an object, independent of time and band */
    oid VARCHAR PRIMARY KEY,  /* object identifier, from the ZTF */
    deltajd DOUBLE PRECISION, /* time difference between last and first detection */
    firstmjd DOUBLE PRECISION, /* time of first detection */
    lastmjd DOUBLE PRECISION, /* time of last detection */
    ndethist INTEGER,  /* number of posible detections above 3 sigma */
    ncovhist INTEGER,  /* number of visits */
    mjdstarthist DOUBLE PRECISION,  /* time of first observation even if not detected, Earliest Julian date of epoch corresponding to ndethist [days]*/
    mjdendhist DOUBLE PRECISION, /* time of last observation even if not detected, Latest Julian date of epoch corresponding to ndethist [days] */
    corrected BOOLEAN, /* whether the object was corrected */
    stellar BOOLEAN, /* whether the object is likely psf shaped */
    ndet INTEGER, /* total number of detections for the object */
    g_r_max DOUBLE PRECISION, /* g-r difference color at maximum */
    g_r_max_corr DOUBLE PRECISION, /* g-r color at maximum*/
    g_r_mean DOUBLE PRECISION, /* mean g-r difference color */
    g_r_mean_corr DOUBLE PRECISION, /* mean g-r color */
    meanra DOUBLE PRECISION,  /* mean right ascension */
    meandec DOUBLE PRECISION,  /* mean declination */
    sigmara DOUBLE PRECISION, /* right ascension dispersion */
    sigmadec DOUBLE PRECISION, /* declination dispersion */
    step_id_corr VARCHAR, /* correction step pipeline version */
    diffpos BOOLEAN, /* whether the first detection was positive or negative */
    reference_change BOOLEAN /* whether the reference image changes */
);
CREATE INDEX ix_object_ndet ON object USING btree (ndet);
CREATE INDEX ix_object_firstmjd ON object USING btree (firstmjd);
CREATE INDEX ix_object_g_r_max ON object USING btree (g_r_max);
CREATE INDEX ix_object_g_r_mean_corr ON object USING btree (g_r_mean_corr);
CREATE INDEX ix_object_meanra ON object USING btree (meanra);
CREATE INDEX ix_object_meandec ON object USING btree (meandec);

CREATE TABLE probability ( /* this table contains the machine learning derived classification probabilities and rankings */
    oid VARCHAR REFERENCES object(oid), /* unique object identifier */
    class_name VARCHAR, /* name of the class */
    classifier_name VARCHAR, /* name of the classifier */
    classifier_version VARCHAR, /* version of the classiifer */
    probability DOUBLE PRECISION NOT NULL, /* probability of the class given a classifier and version */
    ranking INTEGER NOT NULL, /* class probability ranking (1 is the most likely class) */
    PRIMARY KEY (oid, class_name, classifier_name, classifier_version)
);
CREATE INDEX ix_probabilities_oid ON probability USING hash (oid);
CREATE INDEX ix_probabilities_probability ON probability USING btree (probability);
CREATE INDEX ix_probabilities_ranking ON probability USING btree (ranking);
CREATE INDEX ix_classification_rank1 ON probability USING btree (ranking) WHERE (ranking = 1);

CREATE TABLE detection (  /* this table contains information about the object detections, or its light curve. Avoid doing filters on this table in any parameter other than oid */
    candid BIGINT PRIMARY KEY, /* unique candidate identifier */
    oid VARCHAR REFERENCES object(oid), /* unique object identifier */
    mjd DOUBLE PRECISION NOT NULL, /* time of detection in modified julian date */
    fid INTEGER NOT NULL, /* filter identifier  (1=g; 2=r; 3=i)*/
    pid FLOAT NOT NULL, /* program identifier */
    diffmaglim DOUBLE PRECISION, /* limiting difference magnitud */
    isdiffpos INTEGER NOT NULL, /* whether the difference is positive or negative */
    nid INTEGER, /* unique night identifier */
    ra DOUBLE PRECISION NOT NULL, /* inferred right ascension */
    dec DOUBLE PRECISION NOT NULL, /* inferred declination */
    magpsf DOUBLE PRECISION NOT NULL, /* point spread function (psf) difference magnitude */
    sigmapsf DOUBLE PRECISION NOT NULL, /* psf difference magnitude error */
    magap DOUBLE PRECISION, /* aperture difference magnitude */
    sigmagap DOUBLE PRECISION, /* aperture difference magnitud error */
    distnr DOUBLE PRECISION, /* distance to the nearest source in the reference image */
    rb DOUBLE PRECISION, /* ZTF real bogus score */
    rbversion VARCHAR, /* version of the ZTF real bogus score */
    drb DOUBLE PRECISION, /* ZTF deep learning based real bogus score */
    drbversion VARCHAR, /* versio  of the ZTF deep learning based real bogus score */
    magapbig DOUBLE PRECISION, /* large aperture magnitude */
    sigmagapbig DOUBLE PRECISION, /* large aperture magnitude error */
    rfid INTEGER, /* identifier of the reference image used for the difference image */
    magpsf_corr DOUBLE PRECISION, /* apparent magnitude (corrected difference magnitude) */
    sigmapsf_corr DOUBLE PRECISION, /* error of the apparent magnitude assuming point like source */
    sigmapsf_corr_ext DOUBLE PRECISION, /* error of the apparent magnitude assuming extended source */
    corrected BOOLEAN NOT NULL, /* whether the object’s magnitude was corrected */
    dubious BOOLEAN NOT NULL, /* whether the object is dubious or not */
    parent_candid BIGINT, /* identifier of the candidate where this information was generated (this happens if the given detection does not pass the real bogus filter, but a later detection does */
    has_stamp BOOLEAN NOT NULL, /* whether the candidate has an associated image stamp (same as before */
    step_id_corr VARCHAR NOT NULL /* identifier of the correction step */
);
CREATE INDEX ix_ndetection_oid ON detection USING hash (oid);

CREATE TABLE magstat ( /* different statistics for the object divided by band or filter */
    oid VARCHAR REFERENCES object(oid), /* unique object identifier */
    fid INTEGER NOT NULL, /* band or filter identifier (1=g; 2=r; 3=i) */
    stellar BOOLEAN NOT NULL, /* whether we believe the object is stellar */
    corrected BOOLEAN NOT NULL, /* whether the object’s light curve has been corrected */
    ndet INTEGER NOT NULL, /* the object number of detection in the given band */
    ndubious INTEGER NOT NULL, /* the points in the light curve in the given band that we don’t trust  */
    dmdt_first DOUBLE PRECISION, /* lower limit for the the rate of magnitude change at detection in the given band */
    dm_first DOUBLE PRECISION, /* change in magnitude with respect to the last non detection at detection in the given band */
    sigmadm_first DOUBLE PRECISION, /* error in the change of magnitude w.r.t. the last detection in the given band */
    dt_first DOUBLE PRECISION, /* time between the last non detection and the first detection for the given band */
    magmean DOUBLE PRECISION, /* mean difference magnitude for the given band */
    magmedian DOUBLE PRECISION, /* median difference magnitude for the given band */
    magmax DOUBLE PRECISION, /* maximum difference magnitude for the given band */
    magmin DOUBLE PRECISION, /* minimum difference magnitude for the given band */
    magsigma DOUBLE PRECISION, /* dispersion of the difference magnitude for the given band */
    maglast DOUBLE PRECISION, /* last difference magnitude for the given band */
    magfirst DOUBLE PRECISION, /* first difference magnitude for the given band */
    magmean_corr DOUBLE PRECISION, /* mean apparent (corrected) magnitude for the given band */
    magmedian_corr DOUBLE PRECISION, /* median apparent (corrected) magnitude for the given band */
    magmax_corr DOUBLE PRECISION, /* maximum apparent (corrected) magnitude for the given band */
    magmin_corr DOUBLE PRECISION, /* minimum apparent (corrected) magnitude for the given band */
    magsigma_corr DOUBLE PRECISION, /* dispersion of the apparent (corrected) magnitude for the given band */
    maglast_corr DOUBLE PRECISION, /* last apparent (corrected) magnitude for the given band */
    magfirst_corr DOUBLE PRECISION, /* mean apparent (corrected) magnitude for the given band */
    firstmjd DOUBLE PRECISION, /* time of first detection for the given band */
    lastmjd DOUBLE PRECISION, /* time of last detection for the given band */
    step_id_corr VARCHAR NOT NULL, /* correction step id */
    saturation_rate DOUBLE PRECISION /* saturation level for the given band */
);
CREATE INDEX ix_magstats_dmdt_first ON magstat USING btree (dmdt_first);
CREATE INDEX ix_magstats_firstmjd ON magstat USING btree (firstmjd);
CREATE INDEX ix_magstats_lastmjd ON magstat USING btree (lastmjd);
CREATE INDEX ix_magstats_magmean ON magstat USING btree (magmean);
CREATE INDEX ix_magstats_magmin ON magstat USING btree (magmin);
CREATE INDEX ix_magstats_magfirst ON magstat USING btree (magfirst);
CREATE INDEX ix_magstats_ndet ON magstat USING btree (ndet);
CREATE INDEX ix_magstats_maglast ON magstat USING btree (maglast);
CREATE INDEX ix_magstats_oid ON magstat USING hash (oid);

CREATE TABLE ps1_ztf ( /* information about the three closest sources in Pan STARRS */
    oid VARCHAR REFERENCES object(oid), /* unique object identifier */
    candid BIGINT NOT NULL, /* unique candidate identifier */
    objectidps1 DOUBLE PRECISION, /* identifier of the closest source in pan starrs (ps) */
    sgmag1 DOUBLE PRECISION, /* ps g band magnitude */
    srmag1 DOUBLE PRECISION, /* ps r band magnitude */
    simag1 DOUBLE PRECISION, /* ps i band magnitude */
    szmag1 DOUBLE PRECISION, /* ps z band magnitude */
    sgscore1 DOUBLE PRECISION, /* ps star galaxy score */
    distpsnr1 DOUBLE PRECISION, /* distance to closest source in panstarrs */
    objectidps2 DOUBLE PRECISION,  /* identifier of the second closest source in pan starrs (ps) */
    sgmag2 DOUBLE PRECISION, /* g-band PSF magnitude of second closest source from PS1 catalog; if exists within 30 arcsec [mag] */
    srmag2 DOUBLE PRECISION, /* r-band PSF magnitude of second closest source from PS1 catalog; if exists within 30 arcsec [mag] */
    simag2 DOUBLE PRECISION, /* i-band PSF magnitude of second closest source from PS1 catalog; if exists within 30 arcsec [mag] */
    szmag2 DOUBLE PRECISION, /* z-band PSF magnitude of second closest source from PS1 catalog; if exists within 30 arcsec [mag] */
    sgscore2 DOUBLE PRECISION, /* Star/Galaxy score of second closest source from PS1 catalog; if exists within 30 arcsec: 0 <= sgscore <= 1 where closer to 1 implies higher likelihood of being a star */
    distpsnr2 DOUBLE PRECISION, /* Distance to second closest source from PS1 catalog; if exists within 30 arcsec [arcsec] */
    objectidps3 DOUBLE PRECISION, /* Object ID of third closest source from PS1 catalog; if exists within 30 arcsec */
    sgmag3 DOUBLE PRECISION, /* g-band PSF magnitude of third closest source from PS1 catalog; if exists within 30 arcsec [mag] */
    srmag3 DOUBLE PRECISION, /* r-band PSF magnitude of third closest source from PS1 catalog; if exists within 30 arcsec [mag] */
    simag3 DOUBLE PRECISION, /* i-band PSF magnitude of third closest source from PS1 catalog; if exists within 30 arcsec [mag] */
    szmag3 DOUBLE PRECISION, /* z-band PSF magnitude of third closest source from PS1 catalog; if exists within 30 arcsec [mag] */
    sgscore3 DOUBLE PRECISION, /* Star/Galaxy score of third closest source from PS1 catalog; if exists within 30 arcsec: 0 <= sgscore <= 1 where closer to 1 implies higher likelihood of being a star */
    distpsnr3 DOUBLE PRECISION, /* Distance to third closest source from PS1 catalog; if exists within 30 arcsec [arcsec] */
    nmtchps INTEGER NOT NULL, /* Number of source matches from PS1 catalog falling within 30 arcsec */
    unique1 BOOLEAN NOT NULL, /* Whether the first closest object has changed w.r.t the first alert */
    unique2 BOOLEAN NOT NULL, /* Whether the second closest object has changed w.r.t the first alert */
    unique3 BOOLEAN NOT NULL /* Whether the third closest object has changed w.r.t the first alert */
    PRIMARY KEY (oid, candid)
);



## DEFAULT CONDITIONS YOU NEED TO SET
### IF THE 'probability' TABLE is used, use always the next conditions, unless the user explicitly specifies different probability conditions.
- 'probability.ranking' = 1 ; this only return the most likely probabilities, if the user request all ranking probabilities, don't use it.
- 'probability.classifier_name='lc_classifier'
### IF THE 'feature' TABLE is used with 2 or more features, you need to take the following steps, because it is a transposed table (each feature is in a different row).
I. Create a sub-query using the 'probability' TABLE filtering the desired objects.
II. For each feature, you have to make a sub-query retrieving the specific feature adding the condition of its value, taking only the oids in the 'probability' sub-query with an INNER JOIN inside each 'feature' sub-query to retrieve only the features associated with the desired spatial objects.
III. Make an UNION between the sub-queries of each feature from step II
IV. Make an INTERSECT between the sub-queries of each feature from step II
V. Filter the 'UNION' query from step III selecting only the 'oids' that are in the 'INTERSECT' query from step IV
VI. Add the remaining conditions to the final result of step V, using the 'probability' sub-query from step I.
### GENERAL
### Important points to consider
- If the user doesn't specify explicit columns or information that is not in a column, choose all the columns, for example by using the “SELECT *” SQL statement, from ALL the tables used, including the ones from the sub-queries.
- Mantain the EXACT COLUMN names as they are in the database, unless the user explicitly asks you to do so in the request, giving you the new name to use. This is crucial for the query to work correctly.
- Mantain the exact class names as they are in the database, marked with single quotes, for example, 'SNIa'.


# If you need to use 2 or 3 tables, try using a sub-query or INNER JOIN over 'probability' TABLE or 'object' TABLE, or an INNER JOIN between 'probabbility' and 'object', or over an INNER JOIN between 'probability', 'object' and 'magstat', if it is necessary (priority in this order).
# Answer ONLY with the SQL query, do not include any additional or explanatory text. If you want to add something, add COMMENTS IN PostgreSQL format so that the user can understand.
# Finally, join all the steps in a final query, with the following format: 
```sql [FINAL QUERY HERE] ```
DON'T include anything else inside and after your FINAL answer.

# Use the next decomposed planification to write the query:
**Decomposition Plan for the User Request:**

**Goal:**  
Return all objects classified as AGN (Active Galactic Nuclei) that show variability in the r band, but have no detections or show no variability in the g band. Order the features by their value in ascending order, and the final query by oid.

---

### 1. **Identify AGN Objects**

- Use the `probability` table to select objects (`oid`) classified as 'AGN'.
- Apply the default conditions:
  - `probability.ranking = 1`
  - `probability.classifier_name = 'lc_classifier'`
  - `probability.class_name = 'AGN'`
- This subquery will provide the list of oids for AGN objects.

---

### 2. **Define Variability in the r Band**

- Use the `feature` table to identify objects that show variability in the r band.
- Variability can be inferred from features such as:
  - `Std` (standard deviation of the light curve)
  - `ExcessVar` (intrinsic variability amplitude)
  - `Amplitude` (half the difference between the median of the maximum 5% and minimum 5% magnitudes)
- For the r band, `fid = 2`.
- Select oids from the AGN subquery (from step 1) that have a significant value in at least one of these features in the r band.
- Define "show variability" as having a non-zero or above-threshold value for at least one of these features (e.g., `Std > 0`, `ExcessVar > 0`, or `Amplitude > 0`).
- Create a subquery for each feature (Std, ExcessVar, Amplitude) in the r band, filtering for oids in the AGN subquery and the feature value > 0.
- UNION these subqueries to get all oids that show variability in the r band.

---

### 3. **Define No Detections or No Variability in the g Band**

- For the g band, `fid = 1`.
- "No detections" means the object does not have any feature rows with `fid = 1` in the `feature` table.
- "No variability" means that, if there are detections (i.e., feature rows with `fid = 1`), the variability features (`Std`, `ExcessVar`, `Amplitude`) are zero or below a minimal threshold.
- Create two subqueries:
  - **No Detections:** Select oids from the AGN subquery that do NOT appear in the `feature` table with `fid = 1`.
  - **No Variability:** Select oids from the AGN subquery that have feature rows with `fid = 1` and all variability features (`Std`, `ExcessVar`, `Amplitude`) are zero or below threshold.
- UNION these two subqueries to get all oids that either have no detections or show no variability in the g band.

---

### 4. **Combine r Band Variability and g Band Non-Variability/No Detections**

- INTERSECT the oids from step 2 (r band variability) with the oids from step 3 (g band no detections or no variability).
- This gives the set of AGN objects that show variability in the r band but not in the g band.

---

### 5. **Retrieve and Order Features**

- For the resulting oids from step 4, retrieve all their features from the `feature` table.
- Order the features by their `value` in ascending order.
- Order the final result by `oid`.

---

### 6. **Summary of Subqueries and Operations**

- **Subquery 1:** AGN oids from `probability` table (with default conditions).
- **Subquery 2:** r band variability oids (from `feature` table, `fid = 2`, variability features > 0, INNER JOIN with Subquery 1).
- **Subquery 3a:** g band no detections oids (oids from Subquery 1 not present in `feature` table with `fid = 1`).
- **Subquery 3b:** g band no variability oids (oids from Subquery 1 with `fid = 1` and all variability features <= 0).
- **Subquery 3:** UNION of 3a and 3b.
- **Subquery 4:** INTERSECT of Subquery 2 and Subquery 3.
- **Final Query:** Retrieve all features for oids in Subquery 4, order by `value` ascending, then by `oid`.

---

### 7. **Joins and Filtering**

- Use INNER JOINs between `probability` and `feature` tables as needed.
- Use UNION and INTERSECT to combine and filter oids according to the logic above.
- Ensure all filtering is done using the exact column and table names as per the schema.

---

### 8. **Output Columns**

- If the user does not specify explicit columns, select all columns from the `feature` table for the final set of oids.

---

**End of Decomposition Plan.**
# If there is SQL code, use it only as reference, changing the conditions you consider necessary.
# You can join some of the steps if you consider it better for the query. For example, if 2 or more use the same table and are not requested to be different sub-queries, then you can join them.

# Important Information for the query
External Knowledge: 0
Domain Knowledge: 0
 # User Request: ''Return the objects classified as AGN that show variability in the r band, but have no detections or show no variability in the g band. Order the features by their value in ascending order, and the final query by oid.''

CREATE TABLE object ( /* this is the most important table. It contains the main statistics of an object, independent of time and band */

CREATE INDEX ix_object_g_r_mean_corr ON object USING btree (g_r_mean_corr);

CREATE TABLE probability ( /* this table contains the machine learning derived classification probabilities and rankings */
    oid VARCHAR REFERENCES object(oid), /* unique object identifier */

CREATE INDEX ix_classification_rank1 ON probability USING btree (ranking) WHERE (ranking = 1);

CREATE TABLE detection (  /* this table contains information about the object detections, or its light curve. Avoid doing filters on this table in any parameter other than oid */
    candid BIGINT PRIMARY KEY, /* unique candidate identifier */
    oid VARCHAR REFERENCES object(oid), /* unique object identifier */

    fid INTEGER NOT NULL, /* filter identifier  (1=g; 2=r; 3=i)*/
    pid FLOAT NOT NULL, /* program identifier */
    diffmaglim DOUBLE PRECISION, /* limiting difference magnitud */

    ra DOUBLE PRECISION NOT NULL, /* inferred right ascension */
    dec DOUBLE PRECISION NOT NULL, /* inferred declination */
    magpsf DOUBLE PRECISION NOT NULL, /* point spread function (psf) difference magnitude */
    sigmapsf DOUBLE PRECISION NOT NULL, /* psf difference magnitude error */
    magap DOUBLE PRECISION, /* aperture difference magnitude */
    sigmagap DOUBLE PRECISION, /* aperture difference magnitud error */
    distnr DOUBLE PRECISION, /* distance to the nearest source in the reference image */
    rb DOUBLE PRECISION, /* ZTF real bogus score */
    rbversion VARCHAR, /* version of the ZTF real bogus score */
    drb DOUBLE PRECISION, /* ZTF deep learning based real bogus score */
    drbversion VARCHAR, /* versio  of the ZTF deep learning based real bogus score */
    magapbig DOUBLE PRECISION, /* large aperture magnitude */
    sigmagapbig DOUBLE PRECISION, /* large aperture magnitude error */
    rfid INTEGER, /* identifier of the reference image used for the difference image */
    magpsf_corr DOUBLE PRECISION, /* apparent magnitude (corrected difference magnitude) */
    sigmapsf_corr DOUBLE PRECISION, /* error of the apparent magnitude assuming point like source */

CREATE TABLE magstat ( /* different statistics for the object divided by band or filter */
    oid VARCHAR REFERENCES object(oid), /* unique object identifier */
    fid INTEGER NOT NULL, /* band or filter identifier (1=g; 2=r; 3=i) */

    magfirst DOUBLE PRECISION, /* first difference magnitude for the given band */
    magmean_corr DOUBLE PRECISION, /* mean apparent (corrected) magnitude for the given band */
    magmedian_corr DOUBLE PRECISION, /* median apparent (corrected) magnitude for the given band */
    magmax_corr DOUBLE PRECISION, /* maximum apparent (corrected) magnitude for the given band */
    magmin_corr DOUBLE PRECISION, /* minimum apparent (corrected) magnitude for the given band */
    magsigma_corr DOUBLE PRECISION, /* dispersion of the apparent (corrected) magnitude for the given band */
    maglast_corr DOUBLE PRECISION, /* last apparent (corrected) magnitude for the given band */
    magfirst_corr DOUBLE PRECISION, /* mean apparent (corrected) magnitude for the given band */
    firstmjd DOUBLE PRECISION, /* time of first detection for the given band */
    lastmjd DOUBLE PRECISION, /* time of last detection for the given band */
    step_id_corr VARCHAR NOT NULL, /* correction step id */

);
CREATE INDEX ix_magstats_dmdt_first ON magstat USING btree (dmdt_first);

**Decomposition Plan for the User Request:**

**Goal:**  
Return all objects classified as AGN (Active Galactic Nuclei) that show variability in the r band, but have no detections or show no variability in the g band. Order the features by their value in ascending order, and the final query by oid.

---

### 1. **Identify AGN Objects**

- Use the `probability` table to select objects (`oid`) classified as 'AGN'.
- Apply the default conditions:
  - `probability.ranking = 1` (most likely class)
  - `probability.classifier_name = 'lc_classifier'`
  - `probability.class_name = 'AGN'`
- This subquery will provide the list of candidate AGN objects.

---

### 2. **Determine Variability in the r Band**

- Use the `feature` table to assess variability in the r band (fid = 2).
- Select features that indicate variability. Common variability features include:
  - 'Std' (standard deviation of the light curve)
  - 'ExcessVar' (intrinsic variability amplitude)
  - 'Amplitude' (half the difference between the median of the maximum 5% and minimum 5% magnitudes)
- For each AGN object, check if at least one of these features in the r band (fid = 2) is above a certain threshold (e.g., Std > 0, ExcessVar > 0, Amplitude > 0). If the user does not specify a threshold, use > 0 as a generic indicator of variability.
- Create a subquery that INNER JOINs the AGN oids from step 1 with the `feature` table, filtering for the r band and the chosen variability features with value > 0.

---

### 3. **Check for No Detections or No Variability in the g Band**

- For the same set of AGN oids, check the g band (fid = 1) in the `feature` table.
- Two possible conditions:
  - **No detections in g band:** The object has no rows in the `feature` table with fid = 1.
  - **No variability in g band:** The object has rows in the `feature` table with fid = 1, but all relevant variability features (Std, ExcessVar, Amplitude) are zero or below threshold (e.g., <= 0).
- Construct a subquery for AGN oids that either:
  - Do not appear in the `feature` table with fid = 1, or
  - Appear in the `feature` table with fid = 1, but all relevant variability features are <= 0.
- This may require a LEFT JOIN or NOT EXISTS/EXCEPT logic to exclude oids with significant variability in the g band.

---

### 4. **Combine Conditions for Final Object Selection**

- Intersect the results from steps 2 and 3 to get AGN objects that:
  - Show variability in the r band (step 2)
  - Have no detections or no variability in the g band (step 3)
- Use an INNER JOIN or INTERSECT between the subqueries from steps 2 and 3, ensuring only oids meeting both criteria are selected.

---

### 5. **Retrieve and Order Features**

- For the final set of oids, retrieve all their features from the `feature` table.
- Order the features by their `value` in ascending order.
- Order the final result by `oid` as requested.

---

### 6. **Summary of Subqueries and Joins**

- **Subquery 1:** Select AGN oids from `probability` with default conditions.
- **Subquery 2:** Select oids from Subquery 1 with r band variability (feature, fid = 2, variability features > 0).

CREATE TABLE object ( /* this is the most important table. It contains the main statistics of an object, independent of time and band */
    oid VARCHAR PRIMARY KEY,  /* object identifier, from the ZTF */

    mjdendhist DOUBLE PRECISION, /* time of last observation even if not detected, Latest Julian date of epoch corresponding to ndethist [days] */

CREATE TABLE probability ( /* this table contains the machine learning derived classification probabilities and rankings */
    oid VARCHAR REFERENCES object(oid), /* unique object identifier */

**Decomposition Plan for the User Request:**

**Goal:**  
Return all objects classified as AGN (Active Galactic Nuclei) that show variability in the r band, but have no detections or show no variability in the g band. Order the features by their value in ascending order, and the final query by oid.

---

### 1. **Identify AGN Objects**

- Use the `probability` table to select objects (`oid`) classified as 'AGN'.
- Apply the default conditions:
  - `probability.ranking = 1` (most likely class)
  - `probability.classifier_name = 'lc_classifier'`
  - `probability.class_name = 'AGN'`
- This subquery will provide the list of candidate AGN objects.

---

### 2. **Determine Variability in the r Band**

- Use the `feature` table to assess variability in the r band (fid = 2).
- Select features that indicate variability. Common variability features include:
  - 'Std' (standard deviation of the light curve)
  - 'ExcessVar' (intrinsic variability amplitude)
  - 'Amplitude' (half the difference between the median of the max 5% and min 5% magnitudes)
- For this query, select objects with a significant value in at least one of these features in the r band (fid = 2). Define "show variability" as having a value above a certain threshold (e.g., 'Std' > 0, 'ExcessVar' > 0, or 'Amplitude' > 0).
- Join this with the AGN subquery from step 1 to ensure only AGN objects are considered.

---

### 3. **Exclude Objects with Detections or Variability in the g Band**

- For the same set of AGN objects, check the `feature` table for the g band (fid = 1).
- "No detections" in the g band can be interpreted as the absence of any feature rows for fid = 1 for that oid.
- "Show no variability" in the g band can be interpreted as all relevant variability features ('Std', 'ExcessVar', 'Amplitude') being zero or NULL.
- Construct a subquery to find oids that either:
  - Have no rows in `feature` for fid = 1, or
  - Have all relevant variability features in g band (fid = 1) with value = 0 or NULL.
- Exclude any AGN objects that do not meet these criteria.

---

### 4. **Combine Criteria**

- Intersect the list of AGN objects with r-band variability (from step 2) with the list of AGN objects with no g-band detections or variability (from step 3).
- This will yield the final set of oids that satisfy all conditions.

---

### 5. **Retrieve and Order Features**

- For the resulting oids, retrieve all features from the `feature` table (or a subset if only variability features are needed).
- Order the features by their `value` in ascending order.
- Order the final result set by `oid` as requested.

---

### 6. **Detailed Subquery and Join Structure**

- **Subquery 1:** Select oids from `probability` where class is 'AGN', ranking = 1, classifier_name = 'lc_classifier'.
- **Subquery 2:** From `feature`, select oids (from Subquery 1) with fid = 2 and at least one variability feature ('Std', 'ExcessVar', 'Amplitude') > 0.
- **Subquery 3:** From `feature`, for oids in Subquery 1, check for fid = 1:
  - If no rows exist for oid and fid = 1, include the oid.
  - If rows exist, ensure all relevant variability features ('Std', 'ExcessVar', 'Amplitude') are 0 or NULL.
- **Final Selection:** Intersect oids from Subquery 2 and Subquery 3.
- **Feature Retrieval:** For these oids, select all features from `feature`, order by `value` ascending, then by `oid`.

---

### 7. **Summary of Steps**

1. Select AGN objects using the `probability` table with default conditions.
2. Filter these objects for r-band variability using the `feature` table and appropriate variability features (fid = 2, value > 0).
3. Exclude objects with g-band detections or variability (fid = 1, either no rows or all relevant features = 0/NULL).
4. Intersect the results to get oids meeting all criteria.
5. Retrieve all features for these oids, order by feature value ascending, and by oid.

---

**Note:**  
- The query will require multiple subqueries, INNER JOINs, and set operations (INTERSECT, possibly UNION for the g-band logic).
- The use of the transposed `feature` table requires careful handling to ensure correct filtering and joining.
- All table and column names must be used exactly as in the schema.  
- If the user wants all features, select all columns from the `feature` table; otherwise, specify the required features.

CREATE TABLE object ( /* this is the most important table. It contains the main statistics of an object, independent of time and band */

### 1. **Identify AGN Objects with High Classification Probability**
   - Start by querying the `probability` table to select objects (`oid`) classified as 'AGN' by the 'lc_classifier' with `ranking = 1` and `probability > 0.6`.

### 2. **Filter Objects with Light Curves Covering at Least One Year**
   - Join the oids from step 1 with the `object` table.
   - Apply the condition: `deltajd >= 365` (since deltajd is the time difference in days between last and first detection).
   - This ensures the light curve covers at least one year.

### 3. **Filter Objects with at Least 20 Detections in at Least One Band**

This database serves as a repository for information about individual spatial objects, encompassing various statistics, properties, detections, and features observed by survey telescopes.

# The Database has the following tables that can be used to generate the SQL query:

CREATE TABLE object ( /* this is the most important table. It contains the main statistics of an object, independent of time and band */
    oid VARCHAR PRIMARY KEY,  /* object identifier, from the ZTF */
    deltajd DOUBLE PRECISION, /* time difference between last and first detection */
    firstmjd DOUBLE PRECISION, /* time of first detection */
    lastmjd DOUBLE PRECISION, /* time of last detection */
    ndethist INTEGER,  /* number of posible detections above 3 sigma */
    ncovhist INTEGER,  /* number of visits */
    mjdstarthist DOUBLE PRECISION,  /* time of first observation even if not detected, Earliest Julian date of epoch corresponding to ndethist [days]*/
    mjdendhist DOUBLE PRECISION, /* time of last observation even if not detected, Latest Julian date of epoch corresponding to ndethist [days] */
    corrected BOOLEAN, /* whether the object was corrected */
    stellar BOOLEAN, /* whether the object is likely psf shaped */
    ndet INTEGER, /* total number of detections for the object */
    g_r_max DOUBLE PRECISION, /* g-r difference color at maximum */
    g_r_max_corr DOUBLE PRECISION, /* g-r color at maximum*/
    g_r_mean DOUBLE PRECISION, /* mean g-r difference color */
    g_r_mean_corr DOUBLE PRECISION, /* mean g-r color */
    meanra DOUBLE PRECISION,  /* mean right ascension */
    meandec DOUBLE PRECISION,  /* mean declination */
    sigmara DOUBLE PRECISION, /* right ascension dispersion */
    sigmadec DOUBLE PRECISION, /* declination dispersion */
    step_id_corr VARCHAR, /* correction step pipeline version */
    diffpos BOOLEAN, /* whether the first detection was positive or negative */
    reference_change BOOLEAN /* whether the reference image changes */
);
CREATE INDEX ix_object_ndet ON object USING btree (ndet);
CREATE INDEX ix_object_firstmjd ON object USING btree (firstmjd);
CREATE INDEX ix_object_g_r_max ON object USING btree (g_r_max);
CREATE INDEX ix_object_g_r_mean_corr ON object USING btree (g_r_mean_corr);
CREATE INDEX ix_object_meanra ON object USING btree (meanra);
CREATE INDEX ix_object_meandec ON object USING btree (meandec);

CREATE TABLE probability ( /* this table contains the machine learning derived classification probabilities and rankings */
    oid VARCHAR REFERENCES object(oid), /* unique object identifier */
    class_name VARCHAR, /* name of the class */
    classifier_name VARCHAR, /* name of the classifier */
    classifier_version VARCHAR, /* version of the classiifer */
    probability DOUBLE PRECISION NOT NULL, /* probability of the class given a classifier and version */
    ranking INTEGER NOT NULL, /* class probability ranking (1 is the most likely class) */
    PRIMARY KEY (oid, class_name, classifier_name, classifier_version)
);
CREATE INDEX ix_probabilities_oid ON probability USING hash (oid);
CREATE INDEX ix_probabilities_probability ON probability USING btree (probability);
CREATE INDEX ix_probabilities_ranking ON probability USING btree (ranking);
CREATE INDEX ix_classification_rank1 ON probability USING btree (ranking) WHERE (ranking = 1);

CREATE TABLE detection (  /* this table contains information about the object detections, or its light curve. Avoid doing filters on this table in any parameter other than oid */
    candid BIGINT PRIMARY KEY, /* unique candidate identifier */
    oid VARCHAR REFERENCES object(oid), /* unique object identifier */
    mjd DOUBLE PRECISION NOT NULL, /* time of detection in modified julian date */
    fid INTEGER NOT NULL, /* filter identifier  (1=g; 2=r; 3=i)*/
    pid FLOAT NOT NULL, /* program identifier */
    diffmaglim DOUBLE PRECISION, /* limiting difference magnitud */
    isdiffpos INTEGER NOT NULL, /* whether the difference is positive or negative */
    nid INTEGER, /* unique night identifier */
    ra DOUBLE PRECISION NOT NULL, /* inferred right ascension */
    dec DOUBLE PRECISION NOT NULL, /* inferred declination */
    magpsf DOUBLE PRECISION NOT NULL, /* point spread function (psf) difference magnitude */
    sigmapsf DOUBLE PRECISION NOT NULL, /* psf difference magnitude error */
    magap DOUBLE PRECISION, /* aperture difference magnitude */
    sigmagap DOUBLE PRECISION, /* aperture difference magnitud error */
    distnr DOUBLE PRECISION, /* distance to the nearest source in the reference image */
    rb DOUBLE PRECISION, /* ZTF real bogus score */
    rbversion VARCHAR, /* version of the ZTF real bogus score */
    drb DOUBLE PRECISION, /* ZTF deep learning based real bogus score */
    drbversion VARCHAR, /* versio  of the ZTF deep learning based real bogus score */
    magapbig DOUBLE PRECISION, /* large aperture magnitude */
    sigmagapbig DOUBLE PRECISION, /* large aperture magnitude error */
    rfid INTEGER, /* identifier of the reference image used for the difference image */
    magpsf_corr DOUBLE PRECISION, /* apparent magnitude (corrected difference magnitude) */
    sigmapsf_corr DOUBLE PRECISION, /* error of the apparent magnitude assuming point like source */
    sigmapsf_corr_ext DOUBLE PRECISION, /* error of the apparent magnitude assuming extended source */
    corrected BOOLEAN NOT NULL, /* whether the object’s magnitude was corrected */
    dubious BOOLEAN NOT NULL, /* whether the object is dubious or not */

    has_stamp BOOLEAN NOT NULL, /* whether the candidate has an associated image stamp (same as before */
    step_id_corr VARCHAR NOT NULL /* identifier of the correction step */
);
CREATE INDEX ix_ndetection_oid ON detection USING hash (oid);

CREATE TABLE magstat ( /* different statistics for the object divided by band or filter */
    oid VARCHAR REFERENCES object(oid), /* unique object identifier */

    magsigma DOUBLE PRECISION, /* dispersion of the difference magnitude for the given band */
    maglast DOUBLE PRECISION, /* last difference magnitude for the given band */
    magfirst DOUBLE PRECISION, /* first difference magnitude for the given band */
    magmean_corr DOUBLE PRECISION, /* mean apparent (corrected) magnitude for the given band */
    magmedian_corr DOUBLE PRECISION, /* median apparent (corrected) magnitude for the given band */
    magmax_corr DOUBLE PRECISION, /* maximum apparent (corrected) magnitude for the given band */
    magmin_corr DOUBLE PRECISION, /* minimum apparent (corrected) magnitude for the given band */
    magsigma_corr DOUBLE PRECISION, /* dispersion of the apparent (corrected) magnitude for the given band */
    maglast_corr DOUBLE PRECISION, /* last apparent (corrected) magnitude for the given band */
    magfirst_corr DOUBLE PRECISION, /* mean apparent (corrected) magnitude for the given band */
    firstmjd DOUBLE PRECISION, /* time of first detection for the given band */
    lastmjd DOUBLE PRECISION, /* time of last detection for the given band */
    step_id_corr VARCHAR NOT NULL, /* correction step id */
    saturation_rate DOUBLE PRECISION /* saturation level for the given band */
);
CREATE INDEX ix_magstats_dmdt_first ON magstat USING btree (dmdt_first);
CREATE INDEX ix_magstats_firstmjd ON magstat USING btree (firstmjd);
CREATE INDEX ix_magstats_lastmjd ON magstat USING btree (lastmjd);
CREATE INDEX ix_magstats_magmean ON magstat USING btree (magmean);
CREATE INDEX ix_magstats_magmin ON magstat USING btree (magmin);
CREATE INDEX ix_magstats_magfirst ON magstat USING btree (magfirst);
CREATE INDEX ix_magstats_ndet ON magstat USING btree (ndet);
CREATE INDEX ix_magstats_maglast ON magstat USING btree (maglast);
CREATE INDEX ix_magstats_oid ON magstat USING hash (oid);

CREATE TABLE ps1_ztf ( /* information about the three closest sources in Pan STARRS */

Here is a detailed decomposition plan for generating the required PostgreSQL query, following the database schema, context, and advanced query requirements:

---

### 1. **Filter Objects Classified as AGN with High Probability**
- **Subquery 1:**  
  - Use the `probability` table to select objects (`oid`) where:
    - `class_name = 'AGN'`
    - `classifier_name = 'lc_classifier'`
    - `ranking = 1`
    - `probability > 0.6`
  - This subquery will yield the set of oids that are most likely AGN with the required probability.

---

### 2. **Filter Objects with Light Curves Covering at Least One Year**
- **Subquery 2:**  
  - Use the `object` table to select oids where:
    - `deltajd >= 365` (since deltajd is the time difference in days between last and first detection)
  - This subquery will yield oids with at least one year of light curve coverage.

---

### 3. **Filter Objects with at Least 20 Detections in at Least One Band**
- **Subquery 3:**  
  - Use the `feature` table to select oids where:
    - `name = 'n_det'`
    - `value >= 20`
    - This must be true for at least one band (`fid`).
  - The subquery should return oids, the corresponding `fid` (filter id), and the feature version.

---

### 4. **Filter Objects with Large Variations in Corrected Magnitudes**
- **Subquery 4a (g band):**
  - Use the `feature` table to select oids where:
    - `name = 'delta_mag_fid'`
    - `fid = 1` (g band)
    - `value > 1`
    - The feature must be based on corrected magnitudes (as per the feature description, delta_mag_fid uses corrected magnitudes if available).
- **Subquery 4b (r band):**
  - Use the `feature` table to select oids where:
    - `name = 'delta_mag_fid'`
    - `fid = 2` (r band)
    - `value > 0.5`
    - The feature must be based on corrected magnitudes.

---

### 5. **Combine Feature Filters Using INTERSECT and UNION**
- **Step 5.1:**  
  - For each feature filter (from steps 3, 4a, 4b), create a subquery that retrieves oids, value, name, version, and fid, joining with the oids from Subquery 1 (AGN) and Subquery 2 (one year coverage).
- **Step 5.2:**  
  - Use UNION to combine the results of the three feature subqueries (n_det, delta_mag_fid for g, delta_mag_fid for r).
- **Step 5.3:**  
  - Use INTERSECT to find oids that appear in all three feature subqueries (i.e., objects that satisfy all three feature conditions).
- **Step 5.4:**  
  - Filter the UNION result to only include oids present in the INTERSECT result, ensuring all feature conditions are met.

---

### 6. **Retrieve Additional Object Information**
- **Step 6.1:**  
  - For the filtered oids, join with the `object` table to retrieve:
    - `meanra`, `meandec` (mean coordinates)
    - `ndet` (total number of detections)
- **Step 6.2:**  
  - For each oid, retrieve from the `feature` table:
    - `min_mag` and `max_mag` for both g (fid=1) and r (fid=2) bands, using corrected magnitudes.
    - The difference between `max_mag` and `min_mag` in each band, alias as `delta_mag`.
    - For each feature, retrieve `value`, `name`, `version`, and `fid` (aliased as `feature_fid`).

---

### 7. **Assemble the Final Output**
- **Step 7.1:**  
  - Select and output the following columns:
    - `oid`
    - `value`, `name`, `version`, `fid` (as `feature_fid`) from the `feature` table
    - `meanra`, `meandec`, `ndet` from the `object` table
    - `min_mag` and `max_mag` for g and r bands, with their respective `fid` (aliased as `feature_fid`)
    - `delta_mag` for g and r bands (computed as `max_mag - min_mag` for each band)
- **Step 7.2:**  
  - Ensure that the output includes only those oids that satisfy all the above conditions.

---

### 8. **Query Structure and Joins**
- **Step 8.1:**

---

### 9. **Final Filtering and Output**

This database serves as a repository for information about individual spatial objects, encompassing various statistics, properties, detections, and features observed by survey telescopes.
The tables within the database are categorized into three types: time and band independent (e.g., object, probability), time-independent (e.g., magstats), and time and band-dependent (e.g., detection). # The Database has the following tables that can be used to generate the SQL query:

CREATE TABLE object ( /* this is the most important table. It contains the main statistics of an object, independent of time and band */
    oid VARCHAR PRIMARY KEY,  /* object identifier, from the ZTF */
    deltajd DOUBLE PRECISION, /* time difference between last and first detection */
    firstmjd DOUBLE PRECISION, /* time of first detection */
    lastmjd DOUBLE PRECISION, /* time of last detection */
    ndethist INTEGER,  /* number of posible detections above 3 sigma */
    ncovhist INTEGER,  /* number of visits */
    mjdstarthist DOUBLE PRECISION,  /* time of first observation even if not detected, Earliest Julian date of epoch corresponding to ndethist [days]*/
    mjdendhist DOUBLE PRECISION, /* time of last observation even if not detected, Latest Julian date of epoch corresponding to ndethist [days] */
    corrected BOOLEAN, /* whether the object was corrected */
    stellar BOOLEAN, /* whether the object is likely psf shaped */
    ndet INTEGER, /* total number of detections for the object */
    g_r_max DOUBLE PRECISION, /* g-r difference color at maximum */
    g_r_max_corr DOUBLE PRECISION, /* g-r color at maximum*/
    g_r_mean DOUBLE PRECISION, /* mean g-r difference color */
    g_r_mean_corr DOUBLE PRECISION, /* mean g-r color */
    meanra DOUBLE PRECISION,  /* mean right ascension */
    meandec DOUBLE PRECISION,  /* mean declination */
    sigmara DOUBLE PRECISION, /* right ascension dispersion */
    sigmadec DOUBLE PRECISION, /* declination dispersion */
    step_id_corr VARCHAR, /* correction step pipeline version */
    diffpos BOOLEAN, /* whether the first detection was positive or negative */
    reference_change BOOLEAN /* whether the reference image changes */
);
CREATE INDEX ix_object_ndet ON object USING btree (ndet);
CREATE INDEX ix_object_firstmjd ON object USING btree (firstmjd);
CREATE INDEX ix_object_g_r_max ON object USING btree (g_r_max);
CREATE INDEX ix_object_g_r_mean_corr ON object USING btree (g_r_mean_corr);
CREATE INDEX ix_object_meanra ON object USING btree (meanra);
CREATE INDEX ix_object_meandec ON object USING btree (meandec);

CREATE TABLE probability ( /* this table contains the machine learning derived classification probabilities and rankings */
    oid VARCHAR REFERENCES object(oid), /* unique object identifier */
    class_name VARCHAR, /* name of the class */
    classifier_name VARCHAR, /* name of the classifier */
    classifier_version VARCHAR, /* version of the classiifer */
    probability DOUBLE PRECISION NOT NULL, /* probability of the class given a classifier and version */
    ranking INTEGER NOT NULL, /* class probability ranking (1 is the most likely class) */
    PRIMARY KEY (oid, class_name, classifier_name, classifier_version)
);
CREATE INDEX ix_probabilities_oid ON probability USING hash (oid);
CREATE INDEX ix_probabilities_probability ON probability USING btree (probability);
CREATE INDEX ix_probabilities_ranking ON probability USING btree (ranking);
CREATE INDEX ix_classification_rank1 ON probability USING btree (ranking) WHERE (ranking = 1);

CREATE TABLE detection (  /* this table contains information about the object detections, or its light curve. Avoid doing filters on this table in any parameter other than oid */
    candid BIGINT PRIMARY KEY, /* unique candidate identifier */
    oid VARCHAR REFERENCES object(oid), /* unique object identifier */
    mjd DOUBLE PRECISION NOT NULL, /* time of detection in modified julian date */
    fid INTEGER NOT NULL, /* filter identifier  (1=g; 2=r; 3=i)*/
    pid FLOAT NOT NULL, /* program identifier */
    diffmaglim DOUBLE PRECISION, /* limiting difference magnitud */
    isdiffpos INTEGER NOT NULL, /* whether the difference is positive or negative */
    nid INTEGER, /* unique night identifier */
    ra DOUBLE PRECISION NOT NULL, /* inferred right ascension */
    dec DOUBLE PRECISION NOT NULL, /* inferred declination */
    magpsf DOUBLE PRECISION NOT NULL, /* point spread function (psf) difference magnitude */
    sigmapsf DOUBLE PRECISION NOT NULL, /* psf difference magnitude error */
    magap DOUBLE PRECISION, /* aperture difference magnitude */
    sigmagap DOUBLE PRECISION, /* aperture difference magnitud error */
    distnr DOUBLE PRECISION, /* distance to the nearest source in the reference image */
    rb DOUBLE PRECISION, /* ZTF real bogus score */
    rbversion VARCHAR, /* version of the ZTF real bogus score */
    drb DOUBLE PRECISION, /* ZTF deep learning based real bogus score */
    drbversion VARCHAR, /* versio  of the ZTF deep learning based real bogus score */
    magapbig DOUBLE PRECISION, /* large aperture magnitude */
    sigmagapbig DOUBLE PRECISION, /* large aperture magnitude error */
    rfid INTEGER, /* identifier of the reference image used for the difference image */
    magpsf_corr DOUBLE PRECISION, /* apparent magnitude (corrected difference magnitude) */
    sigmapsf_corr DOUBLE PRECISION, /* error of the apparent magnitude assuming point like source */
    sigmapsf_corr_ext DOUBLE PRECISION, /* error of the apparent magnitude assuming extended source */
    corrected BOOLEAN NOT NULL, /* whether the object’s magnitude was corrected */
    dubious BOOLEAN NOT NULL, /* whether the object is dubious or not */

    has_stamp BOOLEAN NOT NULL, /* whether the candidate has an associated image stamp (same as before */
    step_id_corr VARCHAR NOT NULL /* identifier of the correction step */
);
CREATE INDEX ix_ndetection_oid ON detection USING hash (oid);

CREATE TABLE magstat ( /* different statistics for the object divided by band or filter */
    oid VARCHAR REFERENCES object(oid), /* unique object identifier */

    magmin DOUBLE PRECISION, /* minimum difference magnitude for the given band */
    magsigma DOUBLE PRECISION, /* dispersion of the difference magnitude for the given band */
    maglast DOUBLE PRECISION, /* last difference magnitude for the given band */
    magfirst DOUBLE PRECISION, /* first difference magnitude for the given band */
    magmean_corr DOUBLE PRECISION, /* mean apparent (corrected) magnitude for the given band */
    magmedian_corr DOUBLE PRECISION, /* median apparent (corrected) magnitude for the given band */
    magmax_corr DOUBLE PRECISION, /* maximum apparent (corrected) magnitude for the given band */
    magmin_corr DOUBLE PRECISION, /* minimum apparent (corrected) magnitude for the given band */
    magsigma_corr DOUBLE PRECISION, /* dispersion of the apparent (corrected) magnitude for the given band */
    maglast_corr DOUBLE PRECISION, /* last apparent (corrected) magnitude for the given band */
    magfirst_corr DOUBLE PRECISION, /* mean apparent (corrected) magnitude for the given band */
    firstmjd DOUBLE PRECISION, /* time of first detection for the given band */
    lastmjd DOUBLE PRECISION, /* time of last detection for the given band */
    step_id_corr VARCHAR NOT NULL, /* correction step id */
    saturation_rate DOUBLE PRECISION /* saturation level for the given band */
);
CREATE INDEX ix_magstats_dmdt_first ON magstat USING btree (dmdt_first);
CREATE INDEX ix_magstats_firstmjd ON magstat USING btree (firstmjd);

CREATE INDEX ix_magstats_ndet ON magstat USING btree (ndet);
CREATE INDEX ix_magstats_maglast ON magstat USING btree (maglast);
CREATE INDEX ix_magstats_oid ON magstat USING hash (oid);

   - For each AGN object, check the `feature` table for the feature `n_det` (number of detections) in any band (`fid`).

4. **Select Objects with Sufficient Variability in g and r Bands (Corrected Magnitudes)**

  - Filter ID from `magstat` as `magstat_fid` and the initial rise estimate.

- Use the `object.firstmjd` column.
- Only include objects where `firstmjd` is between 60188.0 and 60190.0 (September 1 and 2, inclusive of the first two days).

---

### 3. **Select Objects with Highest Probability for 'SN' in the Stamp Classifier**
- Use the `probability` table:
  - Filter for `classifier_name = 'stamp_classifier'` and `class_name = 'SN'`.
  - Only include rows where `ranking = 1` (highest probability for that classifier/class).
- Join this filtered set to the main object selection.

---

### 4. **Retrieve Probabilities from the Light Curve Classifier**
- Use the `probability` table again:
  - Filter for `classifier_name = 'lc_classifier'` and `ranking = 1` (default condition).
- Join this to the main object selection to get the highest probability for the light curve classifier.

---

### 5. **Identify Fast Risers**
- For each object, in each filter:
  - Find the first detection in the `detection` table (minimum `mjd` for that `oid` and `fid`).
  - Find the last non-detection in the `non_detection` table for the same `oid` and `fid`, with `mjd` less than the first detection's `mjd`.
  - Calculate the time difference (`dt = detection.mjd - non_detection.mjd`).
  - Calculate the magnitude difference (`dm = non_detection.diffmaglim - detection.magpsf`).
  - Compute the rate: `dm/dt`.
  - Only include objects where this rate is at least 0.25 mag/day.
- This requires a subquery or CTE to:
  - For each object and filter, get the first detection.
  - For each first detection, get the last non-detection before it in the same filter.
  - Calculate the rate and filter for those >= 0.25.

---

### 6. **Retrieve Non-Detections for Qualified Objects**
- For objects passing the above filters, retrieve all their non-detections from the `non_detection` table.
- Include `oid`, `fid`, `diffmaglim`, and `mjd`.

---

### 7. **Retrieve Filter ID and Initial Rise Estimate from magstat**
- For each object and filter, retrieve from `magstat`:
  - `fid` as `magstat_fid`
  - The initial rise estimate, which is `dmdt_first` (rate of magnitude change at detection).

- For each qualifying object and filter, output:

- Order the results by `oid`.
- Limit the output to 100 rows.

---

- **Subquery/CTE 1:** Select objects with first detection in the first two days of September.

Here is a detailed decomposition plan for generating the required PostgreSQL query, step by step, using the ALeRCE database schema and all the provided context:

---

### 1. **Identify the Main Selection Table and Columns**
- The main object identifier is `oid`, which is present in all relevant tables.
- The query requires information from the following tables:
  - `object`: for general object information and to filter by first detection date.
  - `probability`: for classification probabilities, specifically for the 'stamp_classifier' and class 'SN'.
  - `magstat`: for filter ID and initial rise estimate (dmdt_first).
  - `non_detection`: for non-detection light curve data.

---

### 2. **Filter Objects by First Detection Date**
- Use the `object` table to select objects whose `firstmjd` is between 60188.0 and 60190.0 (to include both September 1 and 2).
- This will be the initial filter for candidate objects.

---

### 3. **Identify Objects with Highest Probability for 'SN' in 'stamp_classifier'**
- From the `probability` table, select rows where:
  - `classifier_name = 'stamp_classifier'`
  - `class_name = 'SN'`
  - `ranking = 1` (to ensure it is the highest probability class for the object in this classifier)
- Retrieve the `oid` and the associated `probability` value.

---

### 4. **Determine Fast Riser Objects**
- For each object and each filter (fid), determine if the object is a fast riser:
  - Join `magstat` for each object and filter, and use the `dmdt_first` column.
  - A fast riser is defined as `dmdt_first >= 0.25` (since the rate is in magnitudes/day and must be at least 0.25).
- Only include objects and filters where this condition is met.

---

### 5. **Retrieve Non-Detection Light Curve Data**
- For each qualifying object, retrieve all associated non-detections from the `non_detection` table.
- For each non-detection, get the `oid`, `fid`, `mjd`, and `diffmaglim`.

---

### 6. **Retrieve magstat Filter ID and Initial Rise Estimate**
- For each qualifying object and filter, retrieve:
  - `fid` as `magstat_fid`
  - `dmdt_first` as the initial rise estimate

---

### 7. **Combine All Conditions**
- The final set of objects must satisfy all of the following:
  - First detection in the first two days of September (`object.firstmjd` in range)
  - Highest probability in `stamp_classifier` is for class 'SN'
  - Qualify as fast risers in at least one filter (`magstat.dmdt_first >= 0.25`)
- The result should include only non-detection light curve data for these objects.

---

### 8. **Select and Alias Required Columns**
- For each result row, select:
  - `object.oid`
  - `probability.probability` (for 'SN' in 'stamp_classifier')
  - `non_detection.fid` (filter ID for non-detection)
  - `non_detection.diffmaglim` (image difference for non-detection)
  - `magstat.fid` as `magstat_fid`
  - `magstat.dmdt_first` (initial rise estimate)

---

### 9. **Order and Limit Results**
- Order the results by `oid`.
- Limit the output to 100 rows.

---

### 10. **Detailed Subquery and Join Plan**
- **Step 1:** Create a subquery to select all `oid` from `object` where `firstmjd` is in the required range.
- **Step 2:** Join this subquery with `probability` to filter for `classifier_name = 'stamp_classifier'`, `class_name = 'SN'`, and `ranking = 1`.
- **Step 3:** Join the result with `magstat` to filter for `dmdt_first >= 0.25` (fast riser) and retrieve `magstat.fid` and `dmdt_first`.
- **Step 4:** Join the result with `non_detection` on `oid` and `fid` to retrieve all non-detections for the qualifying objects and filters.
- **Step 5:** Select and alias the required columns.
- **Step 6:** Order by `oid` and limit to 100 rows.

---

### 11. **Summary of Required Joins and Filters**
- INNER JOIN between `object` and `probability` (on `oid`), with the specified classifier/class/ranking.
- INNER JOIN with `magstat` (on `oid` and `fid`), with `dmdt_first >= 0.25`.
- INNER JOIN with `non_detection` (on `oid` and `fid`), to get only non-detection data.
- Apply all WHERE conditions as described above.

---

### 12. **Final Output**
- The final result will be a table with columns:
  - `oid`

  - `fid` (from `non_detection`)

  - `magstat_fid` (from `magstat.fid`)
  - `dmdt_first` (from `magstat`, as the initial rise estimate)
- Ordered by `oid`, limited to 100 rows.

CREATE TABLE object ( /* this is the most important table. It contains the main statistics of an object, independent of time and band */
    oid VARCHAR PRIMARY KEY,  /* object identifier, from the ZTF */
    deltajd DOUBLE PRECISION, /* time difference between last and first detection */
    firstmjd DOUBLE PRECISION, /* time of first detection */
    lastmjd DOUBLE PRECISION, /* time of last detection */
    ndethist INTEGER,  /* number of posible detections above 3 sigma */
    ncovhist INTEGER,  /* number of visits */
    mjdstarthist DOUBLE PRECISION,  /* time of first observation even if not detected, Earliest Julian date of epoch corresponding to ndethist [days]*/
    mjdendhist DOUBLE PRECISION, /* time of last observation even if not detected, Latest Julian date of epoch corresponding to ndethist [days] */
    corrected BOOLEAN, /* whether the object was corrected */
    stellar BOOLEAN, /* whether the object is likely psf shaped */
    ndet INTEGER, /* total number of detections for the object */
    g_r_max DOUBLE PRECISION, /* g-r difference color at maximum */
    g_r_max_corr DOUBLE PRECISION, /* g-r color at maximum*/
    g_r_mean DOUBLE PRECISION, /* mean g-r difference color */
    g_r_mean_corr DOUBLE PRECISION, /* mean g-r color */
    meanra DOUBLE PRECISION,  /* mean right ascension */
    meandec DOUBLE PRECISION,  /* mean declination */
    sigmara DOUBLE PRECISION, /* right ascension dispersion */
    sigmadec DOUBLE PRECISION, /* declination dispersion */
    step_id_corr VARCHAR, /* correction step pipeline version */
    diffpos BOOLEAN, /* whether the first detection was positive or negative */
    reference_change BOOLEAN /* whether the reference image changes */
);
CREATE INDEX ix_object_ndet ON object USING btree (ndet);
CREATE INDEX ix_object_firstmjd ON object USING btree (firstmjd);
CREATE INDEX ix_object_g_r_max ON object USING btree (g_r_max);
CREATE INDEX ix_object_g_r_mean_corr ON object USING btree (g_r_mean_corr);
CREATE INDEX ix_object_meanra ON object USING btree (meanra);
CREATE INDEX ix_object_meandec ON object USING btree (meandec);

CREATE TABLE probability ( /* this table contains the machine learning derived classification probabilities and rankings */
    oid VARCHAR REFERENCES object(oid), /* unique object identifier */
    class_name VARCHAR, /* name of the class */
    classifier_name VARCHAR, /* name of the classifier */
    classifier_version VARCHAR, /* version of the classiifer */
    probability DOUBLE PRECISION NOT NULL, /* probability of the class given a classifier and version */
    ranking INTEGER NOT NULL, /* class probability ranking (1 is the most likely class) */
    PRIMARY KEY (oid, class_name, classifier_name, classifier_version)
);
CREATE INDEX ix_probabilities_oid ON probability USING hash (oid);
CREATE INDEX ix_probabilities_probability ON probability USING btree (probability);
CREATE INDEX ix_probabilities_ranking ON probability USING btree (ranking);
CREATE INDEX ix_classification_rank1 ON probability USING btree (ranking) WHERE (ranking = 1);

CREATE TABLE detection (  /* this table contains information about the object detections, or its light curve. Avoid doing filters on this table in any parameter other than oid */
    candid BIGINT PRIMARY KEY, /* unique candidate identifier */
    oid VARCHAR REFERENCES object(oid), /* unique object identifier */
    mjd DOUBLE PRECISION NOT NULL, /* time of detection in modified julian date */
    fid INTEGER NOT NULL, /* filter identifier  (1=g; 2=r; 3=i)*/
    pid FLOAT NOT NULL, /* program identifier */
    diffmaglim DOUBLE PRECISION, /* limiting difference magnitud */
    isdiffpos INTEGER NOT NULL, /* whether the difference is positive or negative */
    nid INTEGER, /* unique night identifier */
    ra DOUBLE PRECISION NOT NULL, /* inferred right ascension */
    dec DOUBLE PRECISION NOT NULL, /* inferred declination */
    magpsf DOUBLE PRECISION NOT NULL, /* point spread function (psf) difference magnitude */
    sigmapsf DOUBLE PRECISION NOT NULL, /* psf difference magnitude error */
    magap DOUBLE PRECISION, /* aperture difference magnitude */
    sigmagap DOUBLE PRECISION, /* aperture difference magnitud error */
    distnr DOUBLE PRECISION, /* distance to the nearest source in the reference image */
    rb DOUBLE PRECISION, /* ZTF real bogus score */
    rbversion VARCHAR, /* version of the ZTF real bogus score */
    drb DOUBLE PRECISION, /* ZTF deep learning based real bogus score */
    drbversion VARCHAR, /* versio  of the ZTF deep learning based real bogus score */
    magapbig DOUBLE PRECISION, /* large aperture magnitude */
    sigmagapbig DOUBLE PRECISION, /* large aperture magnitude error */
    rfid INTEGER, /* identifier of the reference image used for the difference image */
    magpsf_corr DOUBLE PRECISION, /* apparent magnitude (corrected difference magnitude) */
    sigmapsf_corr DOUBLE PRECISION, /* error of the apparent magnitude assuming point like source */
    sigmapsf_corr_ext DOUBLE PRECISION, /* error of the apparent magnitude assuming extended source */
    corrected BOOLEAN NOT NULL, /* whether the object’s magnitude was corrected */
    dubious BOOLEAN NOT NULL, /* whether the object is dubious or not */

    has_stamp BOOLEAN NOT NULL, /* whether the candidate has an associated image stamp (same as before */
    step_id_corr VARCHAR NOT NULL /* identifier of the correction step */
);
CREATE INDEX ix_ndetection_oid ON detection USING hash (oid);

CREATE TABLE magstat ( /* different statistics for the object divided by band or filter */
    oid VARCHAR REFERENCES object(oid), /* unique object identifier */

    magfirst DOUBLE PRECISION, /* first difference magnitude for the given band */
    magmean_corr DOUBLE PRECISION, /* mean apparent (corrected) magnitude for the given band */
    magmedian_corr DOUBLE PRECISION, /* median apparent (corrected) magnitude for the given band */
    magmax_corr DOUBLE PRECISION, /* maximum apparent (corrected) magnitude for the given band */
    magmin_corr DOUBLE PRECISION, /* minimum apparent (corrected) magnitude for the given band */
    magsigma_corr DOUBLE PRECISION, /* dispersion of the apparent (corrected) magnitude for the given band */
    maglast_corr DOUBLE PRECISION, /* last apparent (corrected) magnitude for the given band */
    magfirst_corr DOUBLE PRECISION, /* mean apparent (corrected) magnitude for the given band */
    firstmjd DOUBLE PRECISION, /* time of first detection for the given band */
    lastmjd DOUBLE PRECISION, /* time of last detection for the given band */
    step_id_corr VARCHAR NOT NULL, /* correction step id */
    saturation_rate DOUBLE PRECISION /* saturation level for the given band */
);
CREATE INDEX ix_magstats_dmdt_first ON magstat USING btree (dmdt_first);
CREATE INDEX ix_magstats_firstmjd ON magstat USING btree (firstmjd);

CREATE INDEX ix_magstats_magfirst ON magstat USING btree (magfirst);
CREATE INDEX ix_magstats_ndet ON magstat USING btree (ndet);
CREATE INDEX ix_magstats_maglast ON magstat USING btree (maglast);
CREATE INDEX ix_magstats_oid ON magstat USING hash (oid);

### 1. **Identify Objects with First Detection in the First 2 Days of September**

- Use the `object` table to select objects whose `firstmjd` is between 60188.0 (September 1) and 60190.0 (exclusive, i.e., up to but not including September 3).
- Retrieve the `oid` and `firstmjd` for these objects.

---

### 2. **Determine the Filter (fid) of the First Detection for Each Object**

- For each selected `oid`, use the `detection` table to find the detection with the minimum `mjd` (which should match `object.firstmjd`).
- Retrieve the corresponding `fid` (filter ID) for this first detection.
- This will be used to match the filter in the non-detection and magstat tables.

---

### 3. **Find the Last Non-Detection Before the First Detection in the Same Filter**

- For each `oid` and its first detection `fid`, query the `non_detection` table for entries with:
  - The same `oid`
  - The same `fid`
  - `mjd` less than the first detection `mjd`
- For each, select the non-detection with the maximum `mjd` (i.e., the last non-detection before the first detection).
- Retrieve the `diffmaglim` (limiting magnitude) and `mjd` for this non-detection.

---

### 4. **Calculate the Initial Rise Rate for Each Object**

- For each object, calculate the rise rate as:
  - (non_detection.diffmaglim - detection.magpsf) / (detection.mjd - non_detection.mjd)
  - Use the `magpsf` and `mjd` from the first detection, and `diffmaglim` and `mjd` from the last non-detection.
- Only keep objects where this rise rate is **at least 0.25 magnitudes/day** (i.e., greater than or equal to 0.25).

---

### 5. **Filter Objects by Highest Probability in the Stamp Classifier for Class 'SN'**

- For the remaining `oid`s, use the `probability` table to:
  - Select entries where `classifier_name = 'stamp_classifier'`
  - `class_name = 'SN'`
  - `ranking = 1` (highest probability for this classifier)
- Retrieve the `probability` value for these entries.

---

### 6. **Retrieve Probabilities in the Stamp Classifier and Light Curve Classifier**

- For each qualifying `oid`, retrieve:
  - The probability for `class_name = 'SN'` and `classifier_name = 'stamp_classifier'` (already done above).
  - The probability for `classifier_name = 'lc_classifier'` and `ranking = 1` (highest probability class in the light curve classifier).
- Join these probabilities to the main result set.

---

### 7. **Retrieve All Non-Detections for Each Object**

- For each qualifying `oid`, retrieve all rows from the `non_detection` table (i.e., the light curve non-detections).
- For each, include `oid`, `fid`, `mjd`, and `diffmaglim`.

---

### 8. **Retrieve magstat Information for the First Detection Filter**

- For each qualifying `oid` and the filter ID of the first detection, retrieve the corresponding row from the `magstat` table.
- Include the `fid` as `magstat_fid` and any other relevant columns (at least for the initial rise estimate).

---

### 9. **Assemble the Final Output Columns**

- For each row, include:
  - `oid`
  - Probability in the stamp classifier for class 'SN'
  - Probability in the light curve classifier (highest probability class)
  - Filter ID of the non-detection (`fid`)
  - `diffmaglim` of the non-detection
  - Filter ID from magstat as `magstat_fid`
  - The initial rise estimate (the calculated rise rate)
- Ensure that the results are ordered by `oid`.

---

### 10. **Limit the Results**

- Limit the final result set to 100 rows.

---

### 11. **Summary of Required Joins and Subqueries**

- Subquery 1: Select objects with `firstmjd` in the desired range.
- Subquery 2: For each object, find the first detection and its filter.
- Subquery 3: For each object and filter, find the last non-detection before the first detection.
- Subquery 4: Calculate the rise rate and filter for fast risers.
- Subquery 5: Join with the `probability` table for the stamp classifier (class 'SN', ranking 1).
- Subquery 6: Join with the `probability` table for the light curve classifier (ranking 1).
- Subquery 7: Join with the `non_detection` table to get all non-detections for each object.
- Subquery 8: Join with the `magstat` table for the first detection filter.
- Assemble all required columns, order by `oid`, and limit to 100 rows.

# As a SQL expert with a willingness to assist users, you are tasked with crafting a PostgreSQL query for the Automatic Learning for the Rapid Classification of Events (ALeRCE) Database in 2023. This database serves as a repository for information about individual spatial objects, encompassing various statistics, properties, detections, and features observed by survey telescopes.
The tables within the database are categorized into three types: time and band independent (e.g., object, probability), time-independent (e.g., magstats), and time and band-dependent (e.g., detection). CREATE TABLE object ( /* this is the most important table. It contains the main statistics of an object, independent of time and band */
    oid VARCHAR PRIMARY KEY,  /* object identifier, from the ZTF */
    deltajd DOUBLE PRECISION, /* time difference between last and first detection */
    firstmjd DOUBLE PRECISION, /* time of first detection */
    lastmjd DOUBLE PRECISION, /* time of last detection */
    ndethist INTEGER,  /* number of posible detections above 3 sigma */
    ncovhist INTEGER,  /* number of visits */
    mjdstarthist DOUBLE PRECISION,  /* time of first observation even if not detected, Earliest Julian date of epoch corresponding to ndethist [days]*/
    mjdendhist DOUBLE PRECISION, /* time of last observation even if not detected, Latest Julian date of epoch corresponding to ndethist [days] */
    corrected BOOLEAN, /* whether the object was corrected */
    stellar BOOLEAN, /* whether the object is likely psf shaped */
    ndet INTEGER, /* total number of detections for the object */
    g_r_max DOUBLE PRECISION, /* g-r difference color at maximum */
    g_r_max_corr DOUBLE PRECISION, /* g-r color at maximum*/
    g_r_mean DOUBLE PRECISION, /* mean g-r difference color */
    g_r_mean_corr DOUBLE PRECISION, /* mean g-r color */
    meanra DOUBLE PRECISION,  /* mean right ascension */
    meandec DOUBLE PRECISION,  /* mean declination */
    sigmara DOUBLE PRECISION, /* right ascension dispersion */
    sigmadec DOUBLE PRECISION, /* declination dispersion */
    step_id_corr VARCHAR, /* correction step pipeline version */
    diffpos BOOLEAN, /* whether the first detection was positive or negative */
    reference_change BOOLEAN /* whether the reference image changes */
);
CREATE INDEX ix_object_ndet ON object USING btree (ndet);
CREATE INDEX ix_object_firstmjd ON object USING btree (firstmjd);
CREATE INDEX ix_object_g_r_max ON object USING btree (g_r_max);
CREATE INDEX ix_object_g_r_mean_corr ON object USING btree (g_r_mean_corr);
CREATE INDEX ix_object_meanra ON object USING btree (meanra);
CREATE INDEX ix_object_meandec ON object USING btree (meandec);

CREATE TABLE probability ( /* this table contains the machine learning derived classification probabilities and rankings */
    oid VARCHAR REFERENCES object(oid), /* unique object identifier */
    class_name VARCHAR, /* name of the class */
    classifier_name VARCHAR, /* name of the classifier */
    classifier_version VARCHAR, /* version of the classiifer */
    probability DOUBLE PRECISION NOT NULL, /* probability of the class given a classifier and version */
    ranking INTEGER NOT NULL, /* class probability ranking (1 is the most likely class) */
    PRIMARY KEY (oid, class_name, classifier_name, classifier_version)
);
CREATE INDEX ix_probabilities_oid ON probability USING hash (oid);
CREATE INDEX ix_probabilities_probability ON probability USING btree (probability);
CREATE INDEX ix_probabilities_ranking ON probability USING btree (ranking);
CREATE INDEX ix_classification_rank1 ON probability USING btree (ranking) WHERE (ranking = 1);

CREATE TABLE detection (  /* this table contains information about the object detections, or its light curve. Avoid doing filters on this table in any parameter other than oid */
    candid BIGINT PRIMARY KEY, /* unique candidate identifier */
    oid VARCHAR REFERENCES object(oid), /* unique object identifier */
    mjd DOUBLE PRECISION NOT NULL, /* time of detection in modified julian date */
    fid INTEGER NOT NULL, /* filter identifier  (1=g; 2=r; 3=i)*/
    pid FLOAT NOT NULL, /* program identifier */
    diffmaglim DOUBLE PRECISION, /* limiting difference magnitud */
    isdiffpos INTEGER NOT NULL, /* whether the difference is positive or negative */
    nid INTEGER, /* unique night identifier */
    ra DOUBLE PRECISION NOT NULL, /* inferred right ascension */
    dec DOUBLE PRECISION NOT NULL, /* inferred declination */
    magpsf DOUBLE PRECISION NOT NULL, /* point spread function (psf) difference magnitude */
    sigmapsf DOUBLE PRECISION NOT NULL, /* psf difference magnitude error */
    magap DOUBLE PRECISION, /* aperture difference magnitude */
    sigmagap DOUBLE PRECISION, /* aperture difference magnitud error */
    distnr DOUBLE PRECISION, /* distance to the nearest source in the reference image */
    rb DOUBLE PRECISION, /* ZTF real bogus score */
    rbversion VARCHAR, /* version of the ZTF real bogus score */
    drb DOUBLE PRECISION, /* ZTF deep learning based real bogus score */
    drbversion VARCHAR, /* versio  of the ZTF deep learning based real bogus score */

CREATE INDEX ix_ndetection_oid ON detection USING hash (oid);

CREATE TABLE magstat ( /* different statistics for the object divided by band or filter */

    firstmjd DOUBLE PRECISION, /* time of first detection for the given band */

    step_id_corr VARCHAR NOT NULL, /* correction step id */
    saturation_rate DOUBLE PRECISION /* saturation level for the given band */
);

    distpsnr2 DOUBLE PRECISION, /* Distance to second closest source from PS1 catalog; if exists within 30 arcsec [arcsec] */

    distpsnr3 DOUBLE PRECISION, /* Distance to third closest source from PS1 catalog; if exists within 30 arcsec [arcsec] */
